div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of “Othello'' and of Ford's “Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

MONDAY, OCTOBER 14, 1907..

div.head: RECKLESS RHETORIC.
div.p: Mr. Victor Grayson, one of those members of Parliament who desire to pose as upholders of the rights of the Egyptians to self-government, recently indulged at Hudderfield in a violent attack on Lord Cromer. Referring to the recent money grant made to that distinguished servant of the State, Mr. Grayson said that "the national exchequer had been depleted to fill the maw of an idle and cruel parasite, who was a curse to the race." Never, we imagine, did public speaker offer greater insult to any man, and never was uttered a bigger falsehood or more cruel slander. Surely Mr. Grayson does not think that by using such repulsive phraseology he is helping those whose interests he pretends to have at heart! Surely he can see that by such abusive rhetoric he is harming those whom he would have the world believe he is helping! It is amply evident that such men as Mr. Grayson are but using the advanced Nationalist party of Egypt as a cats-paw to obtain their own end-- a notoriety which would be a disgrace to any man of sincere feeling and true patriotism. The most rapid Anglophobes of this country have never gone so far, even in their most heated moments, to describe Lord Comer as "an idle and cruel parasite," and while decrying his work they confess that it was he who brought riches to the country. Lord Cromer was throughout his career, and is still in his hour of rest, the most devoted friend which Egypt has ever claimed, and during his many years of public life he has proved himself, as a servant to the vast Empire to which he belongs and for which he has striven, unsurpassed in faithfulness. Lord Cromer, lifted the yoke of slavery from the necks of the Egyptians and gave them liberty; he it was who made a bankrupt country rich; to him is due the suppression of bribery and corruption; he is responsible for the reformation of the country's courts and the administration of justice. For such services, for such unparalleled works of wonder, we might say, Lord Cromer is help up to public opprobrium by a youthful M.P., whose ignorance is only deserving of the infants school. But Lord Cromer can afford to disregard the reckless, meaningless rhetoric of an ignorant youth, who has no yet learnt the lesson of self control. He is conscious of the good work which he has done during his long career, and he knows that those of worth and sound judgment, those who have followed the trend of events with an unbiassed mind, and those for whom he has worked are filled with the greatest admiration for his services.

div.head: GERMANY AND FRANCE.
div.p: Referring to the telegram which we publish under this heading on page 5, the statement of the German newspaper apparently is due to the allegation made by a French newspaper recently to the effect that Germany, in view of the present unfavourable condition of her money market, is not in a position to bear the cost of a war. The latest mail from Europe brings a leading article from the "Cologne Gazette," which is said to be semi-officially inspired and headed "Preparedness for War," where these statements of the Parisian Press are opposed. The journal says:- "It would be regrettable if by such false reports doubts as to Germany's military power and preparedness for war were to arise. A belief in this readiness is essential to the support of peace; therefore in the interests of peace such attempts to undermine it are very reprehensible. In 1870 the strength of Germany's finances could not be in any way compared with those which, thanks to the economical development and growing wealth of the country, she has at her disposal to-day. What we could do then we can do to-day in increased measure; if we are now in a position to raise the necessary money for our economic aims by ourselves, neither should we be obliged in time of war to appeal to foreign countries. All concern about raising money should be tranquilly left to us We can have nothing against French newspapers warning their fellow-countrymen against investing their money in German stock; they can keep it or not as they like. We can maintain a calm front towards such counsel; but it seems not only useless, but, for general considerations, not a little dangerous to represent Germany's monetary position as so wretched as to annul the aims of national defence."

div.head: The Olivemoor
div.p: The S.S. "Olivemoor" went into the graving dock this morning.

div.head: European Horses
div.p: Twenty Austrian horses were disembarked this morning from the S.S. "Habsburg."

div.head: Quarantine.
div.p: Plague regulations against arrivals from Myteline in Egyptian ports have been cancelled.

div.head: The Alhambra Theatre
div.p: This evening the Gemma Caimmi Italian dramatic company makes its first appearance at the Alhambra Theatre in Sardon's "Odette."

div.head: War Office.
div.p: Mohamed Said Riza has been appointed clerk to the Recruiting Department, and Yacoub Mikhail to the Financial Secretary's office.

div.head: Omdurman Station.
div.p: Work has already been commenced on the building of a shelter at the Omdurman Central Station. It is expected to be completed before the end of the present month.

div.head: A Tourist Party
div.p: A tourist party numbering twenty-four arrived at Alexandria this morning by the S.S. "Habsburg," and left for Cairo by special train from the Custom house station.

div.head: Collapse of a House
div.p: Still another house has collapsed in Cairo, in the Targoman quarter, with fatal result. Several persons were buried under the ruins and one man when extricated was found to be dead.

div.head: Omdurman Waterworks
div.p: The contract for the tank and pipes requires for the Omdurman waterworks has been given to Messrs Orenstein and Koppel, who agree to deliver the materials required at Khartoum North before December 31.

div.head: School Inspection
div.p: Saad Pasha Zagloul, Minister of Education, has inspected the school of Khalil Aghs, and expressed his congratulations to the Direct Ali Bey Husny on the management of the school and the success gained by the pupils.

div.head: A New Egyptian Company
div.p: La Compagnie Egyptienne Houston Thomson, which has been recently formed in Belgium with a capital of five million francs, has commenced electrical operations in Egypt. The Company was floated by the Credit Franco-Egyptien.

div.head: Italian Consulates in the Sudan.
div.p: Mr. Carlo Rosetti, delegate of the Italian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, who has been entrusted with the establishment of Consulates and commercial agencies in the Sudan, left Cairo yesterday for Assouan on the way to Khartoum.

div.head: Rossia Assurance Co.
div.p: The Rossia Assurance Company of St. Petersburg has entrusted the control of its Egyptian business to Mr. A. Kaden from today, the 14th inst, Mr. Th. de Kolischkine, his predecessor having been appointed by the company to a situation in Russia.

div.head: Mr. Moor and the Press
div.p: The libel actions brought by Mr. Moor, of the Ministry of Public Works, against certain local newspapers for defamatory publications in connection with the Sergani scandals, will come for hearing before the Cairo Mixed Tribumal on the 21st instant.

div.head: Egyptian State Railways
div.p: The commisssion of the Egypt Railways decided at its last meeting to demand credits of L.E. 9,000 for the repairing of lines and stations in the Menoufieh province, and L.E. 10,000 for lighting purposes. The question of issuing return tickets was discussed but no decision was arrived at.

div.head: Egypt and Belgium
div.p: In the review of the report on the commercial relations between Egypt and Belgium by Mr. Charles Rueleus, which appeared in our last issue the total capital of Belgian interests here was given at four hundred thousand francs. This was an obvious misprint for four hundred million francs.

div.head: Cotton Mill Profits
div.p: In a statement issued today Mr. William Tattersall, of Manchester, says the net profit of twenty three cotton spinning companies just declared is equal to 32 per cent per annum on share capital, and 24 per cent per annum on share and loan capital combined. The total share capital of the twenty three mills is £866,234 and loans £315,180.

div.head: Alexandria Swimming Club.
div.p: A detailed account of the fifth annual aquatic sports of the Alexandria Swimming Club, which were held on Saturday, will be found on page five. Some excellent sketches of types of manly beauty were made on this occasion by Mr. Binder, who also took some very successful photographs of the various events, and both sketches and photographs will be on view from this evening at Messrs. Reiser and Binder's in Old Bourse Street.

div.head: Cinderella in Egypt
div.p: Many of our nursery legends have an Egyptian origin, said Mr. C.J. Marshall, lecturing at the New Galley photographic exhibition last week. The story of Cinderella had its counterpart in the land of the pyramids. From time immemorial Egyptian mothers had told their children how a beautiful peasant-girl, while bathing in the Nile, was robbed of her slipper by an eagle. The slipper was taken to the King's palace, and the King- the builder of one of the great pyramids-sought for its wearer and made her his Queen.

div.head: THE LAMBERT AFFAIR
div.p: ACCUSATIONS AGAINST MR. DUNLOP.

Our Cairo Correspondent writes:-M. Lambert's recent letter to the "Temps," in which he attacked the Adviser to the Ministry of Public Instruction together with all his works, with so much vehemence, is still the subject of much comment in Cairo. It is felt that the letter is too serious to be allowed to pass unnoticed, the differences of opinion, which according to M. Lambert existed between himself and the Adviser, are often inevitable in so far as they concern the organization of a large department, but M. Lambert has done more than differ with his chief on matters such as these, he has formulated direct accusations of tyranny and corruption against Mr. Dunlop which call for an equally direct reply. Mr. Dunlop in refusing to make any communication to the press on the subject has only been following one of his well-known principals; it matters little what form his reply make take, provided that a definite answer is made.

The Nationalist, and a portion of the French Press have naturally seized upon the incident with avidity, and in order to combat the damaging influences which it may have made upon that portion of the community which is always lying in wait for an excuse to display its disloyality, it is necessary that the person most directly concerned should make public his side of the questions, when we have no doubt but what a very different aspect of the affair would be seen, and the mountains of the moment would develop into the proverbial mole hill in the end. It is really astonishing that a gentleman of M. Lambert's susceptibility could have remained in such a cesspool of corruption as longas he did.

The question of education, where it bears particularly upon the teaching of one language in preference to that of another, is almost bound to create feelings of dissent, if not of bitterness, between the representatives of the countries involved; and Mr. Lambert would have been more than human if the evident passing away of French as a national language had no occasioned him a pang of regret. He speaks with real bitterness of Mr. Dunlop's anti French programme. Take the facts of the position into review however and it will be evident to all, that such changes in the allocation of time to othe teaching of English as opposed to French, were made, not as M. Lambert appears to imagine for the sole purpose of humiliating the French people, but for the simple reason that such changes were absolutely necessary, if the Egyptians were to profit by the British occupation. The British are in the country as-let us say-guardians of the welfare of the people, training its officers both military and civil under men of our own nationality, what then could be more necessary than that the people should be given every facility of learning the language of its tutors, in order that they may more readily assimilate the ideas and customs which they are called upon to learn. It would be a very strange policy to follow if the British having administered the country for years, should shew no desire to render such administration more easy, and at the same time more effective by extending as far as possible the knowledge of the tounge in which the administrative changes have been wrought.

The increased number of Egyptians who speak the English language is becoming more noticeable every year, while on the other hand there is no appreciable decrease in the number who speak French, the reason being that French still holds its way as the conversational language while English is learnt by the newer generation of officials. There is not the slightest wish on the part of the British to oust the French language from the position which it has held for years, but there is the desire to make the knowledge of English as general as possible, and such a desire is in the interests of the Egyptians and of their country.

So much for the reasons which prompted Mr. Dunlop to act as he did in question where French or English had to be decided upon, for the rest the charges made by M. Lambert are mainly of a personal nature and the reply to them must needs be of the same description.
SUPERIOR MUNICIPAL COMMISSION

The Superior Minicipal Commission met on Saturday morning at the Ministry of the Interior under the presidency of H.E. Ibrahim Pasha Naghib, Under Secretary of State for the Interior, when the following was approved.
1. A credit of L.E. 128,760 for providing potable water to the towns of Damietta, Mellawi, Benba, Bas-el Bar, Damanhour, Mehallet-Kebir, Keneh, Assouan and Manfalout.
2. A credit of L.E. 56, 393 for lighting Mehallet Kebir, Damietta, Mit Ghamr, She- bine-el-Kom and Menout with Mansfield incandescent lamps.
3. A credit of L.E. 4,000 for increasing the annual credits allotted to local commissions
4. A credit of L.E> 4,698 for road making in difference provincial towns. Of thi sum L.E. 1,300 was allotted to Minieh.
5. The appointment of a Chief Engineer for roads in provincial centres.
6. The allocation of indemnity to Mudirieh officials for extra work executed for the local commissions.
7. The examination of the question of allotting to municipalities and local commissions the slaughter-house tax.

div.head: MR. WINSTON CHURCHILL
div.p: ARRIVAL AT PORT SAID
(From our own Correspondent).
Port Said, Monday.
H.M.S. "Venus" with Mr. Winston Churchill, Under Secretary of State for the Colonies, arrived here at noon to-day from Cyprus.

div.head: SIR J. HARRINGTON MARRIED.
div.p: London, Monday.
Sir John Harrington married on Saturday last at Eaglehead, Massachusetts, Amy, daughter of the late Senator McMillan

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive came to Ras el Tin palace this morning from Montazah and received in private audience Sir Vincent Corbett. To-night his Highness will entertain Ghazi Mukhtar Pasha to dinner

div.head: THE PRIME MINISTER.
div.p: Mustaphra Pasha Fahmy, Prime Minister, arrived this morning at Alexandria by the Austrian Lloyd S.S. "Habsburg." He was met on board by the sub-director of customs, and on the quay a guard of police was drawn up under the command of Captain Rundle.

div.head: CASSA DEVELOPMENTS
div.p: Actions will be heard on the reassembling of the Mixed Courts after the long vacations against some local banks for calls made on shares of the last issue of the Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio registered in their names.

The only defence which we can imagine to a call for unpaid capital is fraudulent misrepresentation which certainly cannot be alleged in this case and it is inconceivable to us that any Bank should under the circumstances hesitate to meet its obligations.

At a period when every effort is being made to rehabilitate the credit of Egypt the moral effect is deplorable, nor can we conceive that the syndicate of bankers who were implored to come to the rescue of the market and save the situation in the summer will exhibit any keenness again to assist men who have shown themselves so indifferent to their obligations.

div.head: DEATH OF AN ASSOUAN ENGINEER
div.p: Mr. Basil Pym Ellis, son-in-law of Sir John Aird, M.P., died suddenly at the Paris office of Messrs. Thomas Cook and Son in the Avenue de l'Opera, says the "Express." Mr. Ellis, who fifty seven years of age, was a member of the great engineering firm of John Aird and Sons, and directed much of the work connected with the building of the gigantic dam at Assouan.

div.head: FLATS AT CAIRO.
div.p: Sharia-el-Manakh, Cairo, is shortly to be the scene of a great deal of building. Soliman el Ghoudi Bey has decided to erect a large block of buildings and shops, seven stories high, near the National Hotel. The building will contain twenty residential flats and ten shops. It is situated at the corner of Sharia Soliman Pasha and Sharia el-Manakh and is be be finished within a year. Mr. Robert Williams, F. R. I. B. A., is the architect.

div.head: THE BISSENTWAI MURDERS
div.p: Yesterday the prisoners charged with the murder of the Omdeh, chief cashier, and chier bhaffir of the Bissentwai were again brought before the criminal court, and the two leaders Abou Shanaff Menessy and Moneim Menessy, brothers of the Oulad Ali tribe of Bedonin, were sentenced to death.

div.head: RAILWAY BUILDING DEFECTS.
div.p: The Railway Administration has once more been unfortunate in its choice of contractors for its building work. The new mechanical quarters in Cairo have been built on foundations guaranteed for a period of 10 years by a certain firm of contractors and now that the building is complete it is found that the foundation is faulty and the whole will have to be rebuilt. The railway will of course suffer in as much as it will have to wait for new quarters, but speaking financially it will not be the looser. There have been complaints also regarding the concrete which was used at the new Minieh station. This however was done when it was found necessary to build another station there. The only place which offered a suitable site was on the old canal, and this though of necessity an extremely bad place for foundations was eventually decided upon, knowing however that there was bound to be a certain amount of sinking, concrete of an inferior kind was put in for the time being, and this, owing to the platform having settled as it was expected to do, is now cracking and is abortly to be replaced by concrete of a good quality.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary limits-free discussion.

div.head: HELOUAN'S WATER
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir,-In Lord Cromer's last report a note by Sir Horace Pinching, the then Director General of the Public Health Department, appeared wherein that high official raised the hopes of the numerous residents of this salubrious suburb by stating that "Belouan will be furnished with a Jewell filter plant during 1907." Up to the present there is not the slightest sign of any such installation and our water supply at the present time is rich in mud and slime. In fact, the water here is worse than it has been for several years. These ingredients in our water may no doubt be excellent for an agricultural district from the point of view of deposit, but in as much as Helouan has no claim to being an agricultural region, but is simply and solely a residential town we have no need for such ingredients in our water supply. I may state the evil conditions of our water in many cases impart a perceptible flavour to our fluid.
I am, Sir,
Yours etc.,
A resident of Helouan
HelouanOctober 10th

div.head: PORTS AND LIGHTS ADMINISTRATION.
div.p: THE TRIAL ADJOURNED.

This morning the trial of Socrates Spiro Bey and other officials of the Ports and Lights Administration, accused of corrupt practices, was to have been heard at the Native Court, Alexandria. The hearing, however, was postponed until next month.

div.head: REUTER'S AGENCY
div.p: All the home newspapers of last Monday devote considerable space to obituary notices of Lord Brampton, better known to the English public as Sir Henry Hawkins. Yet Reuters Agency neglected to send a word announcing his death. It will be remembered that the same Agency did no give us the news of the deaths of either Ruskin or Herbert Spencer. Yet over and over again the demise of quite unknown persons is announced. For example on Saturday morning Reuter's Agency announced that the French Senator Hugo had died. The deceased gentleman appears to be quite unknown to fame and a French Cairo contemporary is at a loss to identify him and exclaims:-

L'agence Reuter nous annonce gravement aujourd'hui que M. Hugo, senateur, est mort a Milan on ailleurs en Italie, mais elle neglige de nous dire ce que pouvait bien faire de son vivant l'illustre defunt quit mague son nom celebre de l'autre cote des Aples, est totalement inconnu de ses compatriotes en Egypte. Il est vrai qu'a la foire il y a plus d'un ane qui s'appelle Martin.

D'autre part, on nous suggere que ce nom de Hygo pourrait bien n'etre que le prenom du defunt senateur, et que le nom de famille a du rester au bout du fil; cela n'aurait rien d'extraordinaire pour qui connalt le soin apporte par nos ineffables agences a la transmission de leurs depeches.

div.head: NEW NILE STEAMERS
div.p: La Compagnie des Bateaux Omnibus invited a large number of visitors to take part in the maiden trip of one of their new boats the "Mabruk" yesterday afternoon. The boat went exceedingly well, and a most enjoyable trip to the barrage and back was made. There is excellent accommodation on board, the first class has cabin accomodation in addition to a roomy deck in the forward part of the boat. These two boats the "Mabruk" and the "Fellah" should prove a welcome innovation on the Nile, and we wish these every success.

div.head: OMDURMAN MARKET.
div.p: The Governor of Khartoum met with a number of the leading merchants of Omdurman at the Zabtiah last Thursday morning. The building up of the new market ws among the principal matters considered. It was decided that the floors of the shops to be build should be 30 centimetres above the level of the street, the object being to avoid the inundation of the shops during the rainy season.

The Governor announced that after full consulation with the Works Department, it was found that the projected water-works could not be completed before next April. Special arrangements have therefore to be made for supplying the water needed for building. A contract will be made with some individuals who will agree to erect one or more pumps over some public well in the neighbourhood of the market place, and sell the water at certain rates to be agreed upon by the contractor and the local authorities.

One of the merchants present called the attention of the Mudir to the fact that though the ownership of many pieces of land in Omdurman has already be settled no titles have yet been given to the proprietors; and if any of them wish to sell or mortgage their lands, as it often seems advisable or unavoidable, they are unable to do so for lack of proper documents. It was pointed out, however, that parties interested may apply to the Survey Officer at Omdurman, and upon payment of a fee of five shillings, a title for the land together with a plan showing its dimensions and boundaries will be given to the applicant. ("Sudan Times," Oct. 7.)

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Among those due to arrive this evening by the S.S. "Schleswig" are Prince Said Pasha Halim, Youssef Pasha Shakour, Miralai Young Bey, and Miralai Stanton Bey.
Mr. Machell, Adviser to the Interior, has arrived in Alexandria from Cairo.
Sir Vincent Corbett is staying at the Savoy Palace Hotel, Alexandria.
Sir Auckland Colvin, Chairman of the Delta Light Railways and of the Khedivial Mail Company is still indisposed and will probably not come to Egypt.
Dr. Abbate Pasha, has brought out "Athenes for 1906," a lecture which he delivered at the Greek Club and at the Khedivial Geographical Society.

Mr. and Mrs. George Royle and their daughter Mrs. C. W. Maclean, wife of Kaimakam Maclean Bey, commanding the 16th Battalion, Egyptian Army, at Kassals, and their niece Miss Muriel Bernes Lawrence are leaving London on the 19th inst. by the P. and O.S.S. "Caledonia" and are due at Port Said on the 1st prox.

Bimbashi Jennings Bramley, of the Egyptian Army, while on his way to England on leave recently, had an audience of the Emperor Menelik, by whom he was well received. The visit was not of a political or official nature. The officer happened to be at Gambella at the time, and he chose to proceed to England by way of Abyssinia.
Mr. and Mrs. Hewat and family arrived at Alexandria yesterday morning by the S.S. "City of Venice."
Major le Breton, Managing Director of the Delta Light Railways, and Captain Adams, Agent and General Manager of the same company, are leaving London together for Cairo on the 28th inst.
Mr. Percy Le Breton, barrister at law, left London on Friday for Cairo by the P. & O. Brindisi express and is due at Cairo on Wednesday.
Mr. H. R. Mansfield, M.P., who has had to cancel his engagements owing to illness, proposes visiting Egypt next month.
Mr. Harrington has been transferred as postmaster from Suez to Port Said to replace Salib Bey Claudius, appointed chief inspector.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ANTROPOLOGY.
div.p: Dr. Hamy, on retiring from the presidency of the Society of Anthropology of Paris, delivered a lecture on the human figure in the monuments of ancient Egypt. The proto-Egyptian figures in ivory and terra-cotta are described as of a modest, rustic, and popular type of art. Those of the earlier dynasties of Manetho are more simple and more refined. Dr. Hamy maintains his opinion as to the persistence of type between the ancient mummy portraits and the fellaheen of our own day. He adduced in evidence the famous wooden figure called the Sheik-el-Beled, and discusses in detail several of the cast of sculptures made by Prof. Flinders Petrie for the British Association Committee, comparing them with modern types. He comments on the ethnographic value of the portrait figures of men of other nations in captivity, as representing various African types.

div.head: POLO TOURNAMENT
div.p: The first polo tournament of this seasonwas played on the K.S.C. grounds on Thursday 10th and Saturday 12th inst.

The matches were most interesting, it being an open question until the very end which team would win. The tournament was played on the American lines, 7 teams competing, each team playing one chukker with each of the other teams, and the team which scored most goals after deducting the goals score against it, won the tournament. The teams were as follows:-
"A." Mr. Schreiber, Mr. Cobden, Major Posonby, Mr. Kirkpatrick.
"B." Mr. Sherlock, Mr. Wylie, Mr. Watts Russell, Capt. Bartlett.
"C." Mr. Warde Adlam, Capt. Holland. Sir W. Barttelot, Capt. Bayley.
"D." Mr. Bingham, Mr. Crake, M. Merriman, Capt. Stoney.
"E." Capt. Bridgenater, Mr. Clayton, Mr. Burnham, Mr. Marsham.
"F." Mr. Hadow, Capt. Nixon, Lord Lanesborough, Capt. Kennedy.
"G." Mr. Campbell, Mr. Thompson, Mr. Tollemache, Major Gillson.
Scores:-
C + 4 goals. Winners.
A + 3 goals.
B + 3 goals.
G + 3 goals.
D - 4 goals.
E - 3 goals.
F - 6 goals.
The winning team ably captained by Capt. Bayley are to be congratulated on their win. Capt. Barlett for B team, Major Gillson for G and Mr. Schreiber for A all played excellent polo.

div.head: ZAGAZIG RACING CLUB
div.p: The above club has now been put on a permanent basis. The Membership is thrown open to any resident in Egypt. Racing members will pay an annual subscription of L.H. 2 and non racing Members L.E. 1. No one shall be entitled to race unless he has paid his subscription as a racing member. Members will have the privilege of admission to a special stand at reduced rate. Arrangements have been made for the acquisition of a suitable site for the course and it is intended to hold 3 meetings this year on 29th November- 24th January 1908-6 Marobth 1908:
Subscriptions can be sent to and further information obtained from:
The Hon. Secretary
Zagazig Racing Club.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui el midi)

Le marche, favorablement influence par le Stock Exchange, a fait preuve de soutien; plusieurs valeurs ont meme beneficie d'une nouvelle avance, qui a ete pour quelqies unes fort appreciable. Dans l'empomble, pourtant, on s'a ttendait a mieax et la vlotute, un pea plus faible que le debut, a ete une desillusion pour un certain nombre. Inutile d'ajouter que les transactions sout reateas clarsombeset limited en comme importance a quatre ou cinq valeurs. Malgre le flechissement de la fin, la tendunce demeure plutot ferme.

Parmi les titres en faveur qui ont ete l'objct de la plupart des echanges il faut eiter l'Agricole, le Comptoir, la Cassa di Sconto et l'Union Foneiere. En Behera il s'est produit une demande tres active qui n'a quere eu d'autre resultat que de faire monter le cours de 22 1/4 23 1/2 faute de vendears. Il a'agirait d'aeheteurs serienx. L'Agricole, favoriese d'achats de la part d'arbitragiates pour compte de Londres, a progrease de ce chef de 8 5/16 a 8 7/16, prix anquel elle a cleture acheteurs. La Cassa, qui continue a ecouler parpetits paquets son enorme portefeuille titres, a gagne 50 centimes a 54 1/2. De jour en jour plus demandree, l'Union Fenciere s'est avancee de 4 15/16 a acheteurs. Quant an Comptoir, apres avoir ouvert en pleine effervescence a 3 3/8 avec affaires relativement nombreuses, il a fini plus faible a 3 3/16 l'ancienne action et 3 1/4 la nouvelle, soit au meme niveau que vendiedi dernier; la fondateur a meme perdu 1/4 a 2 1/4.

D'abord recherchee avec quelques rres transactions, la National Bank a termine efforte a 22 1/16, a cause d'ordres de vente provenant du Cairo. Ce prix n'en constitute pas moins une plus value de 1/8.
Il y a eu egalement quelques afrarres en Lunghis et Levant, tandis que l'United a ete totalement negligue a 9/32 vendeurs l'action et 1 7/16 la fondateur, contre 9/32 achaeur et 1 1/2 [NON-LEGIBLE].

La Delta Light a flechi de 10 5/16 a 10 1/4, les Jouissances Eaux du Cairo de 135 a 194 et les Nungovieh Hotels de 18 3/4 a 17 1/2. D'astre part, l'Obligation Credit Fongier ancienne emission a progresse de 303 a 304, tandis que la nouvelle a retrograde de 257 a 256 1/12 vendeurs. L'Urbaine a hausse de 3 13/16 a 3 7/8.

Parmi les titres d'ordre secondaire, la Delta Land arecule de 1 23/32 a 1 21/32 et la Building Lands de 2 5/16 a 2 1/4, tandis que l"ordinary Khedivial Mail a avamou de 21/- a 21/3 et la Levant de 9/16 a 19/32.
Il a ete vendu es matin aux enecheres publiques 100 actions anciennes Upper Egypt Hotels a 2 7/8 et 40 nouvelles a 2 1/2, 200

Lunghis a 21/64, 500 United a 17/64, 100 Delta Land 1 43/64, 50 actions anciennes Compoir Financier a 3 19/64, 25 Building Lands a 2 5/16, 25 Credit Franco-Egyptien a 4 11/32 et 200 Land and General Trust (Hooker) a 25/64. Il sera vendu demain 200 autres Hooker et 100 Oasis (Corporation of Western Egypt).

div.head: LA BELGIQUE ET L'EGYPTE.
div.p: Nous acons le plaisir de publier a ce sujet l'article suivant de M. Charles Ruelens, Licencie en Sciences Commerciales et Consulaires et Boursier Commercial du Gouvernement Belge en Egypte:

Le Recueil Consulaire Belge vient de publier le rapport de Monsieur le Baron de Gaiffier d'Hestroy, Ministre de Belgique au Caire sur la situation economique et commerciale de l'Egypte en 1907. Ce rapport est prticulierement interessant, parce qu'il donne un apercutres exact de la situation de l'Egypte au moment on la crise a eclate, c'est-a-dire a l'epoque ou vu l'engouement general tout le monde se demandait a quoi l'on allait aboutir.

C'est aussi le premier document officiel sur les preliminaires de l'epoque actuelle public par une des puissances commerciales brillamment representee sur le marche egyptien par un chiffre d'importations touhours croissants. Aussi pour ce motif a t-il une place speciale dans l'ensemble des documents qui formeront d'ici a quelques mois ce que l'on pourra appeler la bibliographie de la crise.
"L'Egypte, dit M. le Baron de Gaiffier
"comme entree en matiere, - offre aux pro-
"ducteurs de tous les pays, un marche incom-
"parable, dont nos fabricants semblent encore
"ignorer l'etendue si on eo juge par le peu d'ef-
"forts qu'ils accomplissent, a quelques excep-
"tions pres, en vue de s'y implanter - L'E-
"gypte importe des matieres premieres, du
"fer, de l'acier, du combustible, des cereales
"et des produits manufactures depuis les plus
"communs jusqu'aux plus luxueux. Et elle en
"importera toujours davantage pour vien des
"motifs dont les deux principaux sont que
"l'industrie locale se developpe peu, tandis
"que le pays s'enrichit beaucoup grace a la
"sage administration qui a ete inauguree il
"y a 25 ans."

Dans le course de son travail, le Ministre de Belgique passe successivement en revue l'Industrie actuelle du pays; il examine ensuite les causes de l'enrichissement du pays: les conditions climateriques toutes speciales, l'extension continue de l'aire cultivable, la situation financiere favorable, l'accroissement non interrompu des importations et des exportations; et il constate qui l'augmentation considerable durant ces dernieres annees du nombre des banques et des affaires traitees par ces etablissements du credit est aussi un indice non moins important de l'activite et de la prosperite commerciale de l'Egypte.
Parlant des societes nouvelles, M. de Gaiffier constate que "l'rnrichissement rapide du pays
"et surtout la hausse formidables des terrains
"ont fait naitre a cote des banques une foule
"de societes. Pendant l'annee 1905, il a ete
"fonde 30 nouvelles societes pendant que 10
"anciennes augmentaient leur capital. En
"1906, la progression a ete beaucoup plus
"rapide encore et d'apres des documents que
"j'ai sous les teux, le nombre des creations
"nouvelles a excede 47. A la fin de l'annee
"1906 et au commencement de l'annee cou-
"rante nous acons assiste ici a une veritable
"debauche de titres."

Passant ensuite a la question dela speculation sur terrains, le Ministre de Belgique considere que le succes des quartiers nouveaux crees est difficile a prevoir et dependra surtout de la facilite des moyens de communication plutot que de leur eloignement et aussi des travaux publics et des amenagements qui y seront faits. De plus: "Pendant la periode de spe-
"culation, on a schete non pas pour construire,
"mais pour revendre. La grande majorite des
"constructionsest anterieure a ce mouvement.
"Elles ne repondent pas aux besoins du moment et aux capitaux investis. L'augmenta-
"tion des loyers ne pourrait pas compenser la
"mauvaise utilisation des terrains. Encore ce
"moyen n'est-il a la portee que de ceux qui
"ont un terrain construit, le fut-il tres mal.
"Les proprietaires des terrains nus, et ils sont
"legion, se trouvent avoir des capitaux
"morts. - Les proprietaires qui auront
"les moyens dedoterleurs terrains de maisons
"en rapport avec les conditions nouvelles
"n'auront rien a craindre. Les autres qui se
"sont engages dans le mouvement avec l'es
"poir de revendre sont exposes a de cruel-
"les deceptions. Dussent-elles etre suivies
"d'executions, de ventes forcees et meme de
"quelques ruines, celles-ci ne pourraient at-
"fecter en rien la situation ecomique du
"pays".
(a suivre)

div.p: Our uncertain climate is responsible for many ailments, of which few entail more suffering than Rheumatism. Yet the fact is not fully recognised that Rheumatism's acute agonies are the result of a vitiated condition of the Blood, and only when the veins are replenished with new, good blood can the poisons causing Rheumatism be driven out of the system. The one great remedy capable of building up and purifying the blood is Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People; and the manner in which they cure Rheumatism is illustrated in the case of Mrs. Rooney, 51, Hayes-street, Haslingden, Lancs.

"In spite of warm clothing during changeable weather, I was attacked by Acute Rheumatism," she said, "and it threatened to ruin my constitution. The pains began in my hands, and gradually spread to my feet. All my joints became inflamed, and pains shot through my limbs and muscles day and night, nearly driving me mad. I couldn't work, and I couldn't sleep. Indeed, I could not even bear the weight of bedclothes upon my body. My hands became so contracted that I was crippled in every finger. Then my digestion was affected, and food caused sharp pains through my chest and back. The least change in the weather increased the tortures of Rheumatism, and every draught punished me. I fought hard with every means in my power to conque the Rheumatism, and besides taking medicine I applied powerful embrocations, but nothing gave hope of the least improvement. My breathing became difficult and the least excitement caused my heart to palpitte distressingly, while all my strength vanished.

Friends then advised me to take a course of Dr. Williams' Pink Pills, and I bought some, though I had no hope of ever being well again. To my joy I found this wonderful medicine gradually restoring my strength. After the third box I was well on my way to health, and after the sixth box I felt a tingling through my veins, and a comfortable warmth all over my body. I slept well at night, and food no longer caused indigestion. My breathing was easy, and as I continued Dr. Williams' Pink Pills the inflammation left me, my joints grew supple, and every trace of Rheumatism vanished. Dr. Williams' Pink Pills cleared my veins of all the poisons of Rheumatism and gave me rich, pure blood."

Not only Rheumatism but all diseases resulting from bad or impoverished blood have been cured repeatedly by Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People: they are invaluable in Anaemia, General Weakness, Indigestion, Eezema, Sciatica, Neuralgia, Nervous Disorders, Paralysis and Ladies' Ailments. div.head: ABD EL AZIZ INTERVIEWED.
DESIRES DEPARTURE OF FRENCH.
WISH TO VISIT ENGLAND
div.p: Abd-el-Aziz, in the course of an interview, granted to Reuter's representative here, said that he hoped that, God willing, the country would triumphantly emerge from the crisis. If the French would depart he would guarantee peace, otherwise he feared continual outbreak. He intends to march against Mulay Hafid if diplomacy fails.

Abd-el-Aziz said; "You have seen the Japanese fight, are my people as brave?" The correspondent answered: "Yes, but they are unlearnt in modern methods of warfare." The Sultan smilingly said: "No, they are every the same." He expressed a desire to see England but doubted the feasibility of a visit. (Reuter)
Rabat, October 13.
M. Regnault has conferred with Ben Sliman on litigious affairs and the financial situation. (Havas)
Tangier, October 13.
It is announced that Moulay Hafid wanting warms has applied to German firms, who require advanced payment. (Havas)

div.head: LIEBKNECHT SENTENCED.
GUILTY OF TREASON.
A LENIENT SENTENCE
div.p: The socialist Karl Kiebknecht has been sentenced here to 18 months' confinement in a fortress for propagating anti-militarist doctrines and thereby being guilty of treason. The prisoner's defence was eloquent. He made a striking oration expounding his views. The sentence is far more lenient than the prosecution demanded. (Reuter)
Liepzig, October 12.
M. Liebknecht has been condemned to 18 months' detention in a fortress for propagating anti militarism. (Havas)

div.head: GERMANY AND FRANCE
RENTE ON PARIS BOURSE.
div.p: The "North German Gazette" declares that, contrarily to what has been published in certain French papers, the Council of Ministers has not examined the question of permitting the quotation of the German "rente" on the Paris Bourse. The paper adds that the German Government will not occupy itself with this question. The lucubrations published on this subject are devoid of practical significance and can only lead French public opinion into error so long as it is founded on the idea that the German Empire is in need of financial aid, an idea which is entirely baseless. The paper, however, believes that these erroneous views are not shared in serious political circles in France. (Reuter)

div.head: EMPEROR FRANCIS JOSEPH.
COUGH LESS TROUBLESOME
div.p: The Emperor's temperature is high, and his appetite slight, but his cough is less troublesome (Reuter)
The Emperor's condition yesterday evening was less favourable and coughing disturbs his sleep. The fever is intermittent.
(Later). It is officially stated that the Emperor passed a very good night. His general condition is not unfavourable. (Reuter)
The temperature of the Emperor has risen as on former days, but he passed a better day. (Havas)

div.head: KING LEOPOLD ILL
div.p: The King is reported to be suffering from a serious attack at gout at Royat (France)
(Reuter)

div.head: STRIKE AT MILAN.
FIERCE FIGHTING.
div.p: A general strike has suddenly been proclaimed here. Large factories have been closed and nearly all the tramway and railway employes are idle. A few trains are still running. (Reuter)
A fight was caused by the strikers hindering the workers. The strikers committed violences. Carabiniers were drawn. Several were wounded. (Havas)
10,000 strikers marched to the Labour Exchange shouting and singing.
A general strike has been proclaimed at Bologna in sympathy with Milan.
(Later). The printers and gasmen have resumed work. The Bologna strike has ceased.
(Reuter)
The railway staff has resumed work. (Havas)

div.head: THE GREEKS IN CRETE.
ORGANISATION OF MILITIA.
div.p: 23 Greek officers and the proportionate number of non-commissioned officers are going to Crete in order to organise the militia. M. Theotokis, addressing them prior to their departure, exhorted them to prove that Greece was worthy of the confidence of Europe. (Reuter)

div.head: NEW GREEK TOWNS.
FOUNDATIONS LAID BY CROWN PRINCE.
div.p: The Crown Prince, attended by numerous notabilities, laid near Almyro yesterday the foundations of the two new towns Achialos and Euxeinoupolis, which the Government is building the accomodate Greek refugees from Bulgaria. The foundations will be laid tomorrow for another name Philippopoli. The Major of Volo delivered a patriotic speech denouncing the excesses which caused the exodus. (Reuter)

div.head: TURKEY'S POOR HARVEST.
FREE IMPORT OF CORN.
div.p: In consequence of the poor harvest in Turkey foreign corn will be imported free to Constantinople provisionally. Flour will pay back 6% (Havas)

div.head: S.S. "CYPRESS" FOUNDERS.
22 LIVES LOST.
div.p: The streamer "Cypress" foundered during a terrific storm on Lake Superior. There was only one survivor, 22 persons have been drowned. (Reuter)

div.head: FRENCH INCOME-TAX.
div.p: M. Caillaux, in a speech at La-Ferte-Bernard, defended the income tax proposal. (Havas)

div.head: THE PERSIAN CONSTITUTION.
div.p: The "Times" learned from Teberan that the Shah has signed the Constitution. (Reuter)

div.head: THE FLOODS IN FRANCE
div.p: The floods have caused a dozen deaths.
(Havas)
Severe floods continue in the south of France and in Spain. Many persons have been drowned and the railways interrupted. (Reuter)

div.head: MR. WINSTON CHURCHILL.
div.p: Larnaca, October 14.
Mr. Winston Churchill received the Patriarch Anchialos of Alexandria and discussed with him the Archbishopric question. (Reuter)

div.head: AMBASSADORSHIP FOR COUNT POURTALES.
div.p: Berlin, October 12.
Count Pourtales, now at Munich, has been appointed Ambassador at St. Petersburg.
(Reuter)

div.head: ALEXANDRIA SWIMMING CLUB.
div.p: SATURDAYS AQUATIC SPORTS
A RECORD ATTENDANCE

Under excellent weather conditions, pleasant alike to participator and spectator, the fifth annual aquatic sports of the Alexandria Swimming Club (which is affiliated to the Royal Life Saving Society and the Southern Counties Amateur Swimming Association, England) were held on Saturday in the New Graving Dock, Gabbary, before a record number of spectators. The reserved enclosure for the guests of the club was crowded to its utmost with notabilities of Alexandria and several members and visitors from Cairo, every seat along the sides of the dock was occupied, and those standing were almost as many. The dock had been most lavishly decorated for the occasion and presented a very gay appearance with its abundant surrounding of waving bunting and multi-coloured satayer sheltered enclosured, not to mention the bright and varied customes of the fair sex, whose number were larger than ever. The swimming club sports have been popular since the date of their inauguration, and on Saturday proof was given that their popularity is ever-increasing.

Each successive year witnesses an increased number of competitors, a larger crowd of spectators, keener competition, and more satisfactory results. Founded in 1903 with a membership of six, the Club now musters at full roll call nearly 300 members, among whom almost every nationality of cosmopolitan Egypt is represented.

Its value, the good work it does in teaching the boys to be the noblest of all men, sportsmen, is recognised and supported by our greatest men. At its head as President is the Earl of Cromer, and its Vice-Presidents include Prince Aziz Pasha Hassan, Sirdar Sir Reginald Wingate Pasha, Mahmoud Pasha Sidky, Herbert J. Gedge Pasha, H.B.M.'s Consul General E.B. Gould, Major-General G. M. Bullock, A. Luzzato Pasha, A. Chitty Bey, W.P. Chataway Bey, N. T. Borton Bey, the Ven. Archdeacon A. Ward, and Messrs. G.B Alderson, F. Allen, P.W. Carver, C.I. Choremi, T.A.F. Critchley, E.A. Giles, J. Hewat, H.P. Kingham, H.F.C. Parkinson, and Percy Smith. To this it must be added that the Khedive has extended his patronage to the Club and on Saturday his Highness was represented by Lewa Watson Pasha, who expressed to Mr. Walter F. Sargeant, chairman of the Club, the great pleasure which the Sovereign felt in according his support to a club, whose object was to imbue the youth of Alexandria with the finest characteristics of man, sportsman-like feeling and action throughout like. The Governor of Alexandria, Mustapha Pasha Ibadi, was represented by his Secretary, D. Beneducci Bey, and Mr. and Mrs. E.B. Gould were also present. Among others we noticed Mr. and Mrs. N. T. Borton Bey, Mr. H.P. Kingham, Mr. and Mrs. P.W. Carver, the Ven. Archdeacon and Mrs. Ward, Mr. Ambroise A. Ralli, Mr. G. Alderson, Mr. E.W.P. Foster, Mrs. and the Misses Purvis, Mr. and Mrs. E.A. Giles, Mr. Edmund Carver, Mr. and Mrs. G.C. Stevenson, Mr. W. Delanoy, Mr. F.T. Woolley, Mr. and Mrs. Errol Kerr, Mr. C. Tchiboudjian, Mr. F. Leveaux, and many others. The Sirdar wrote regretting his inability to be present.

Before turning to the events of the sports we would draw attention to the value of such a club as the Alexandria Swimming Club. Swimming, to an equal degree to any sport, teaches a person to act promptly and wisely, and it must be remembered that no art in the world can vie with swimming in life-saving. It is a sport which trains a boy to be a man, who is already ready to answer to his country's call, and as such it deserves the fullest support which can be accorded. We have before expressed the opinion that it would be a wise step of the Municipality to build a public swimming bath in Alexandria, and this opinion we re-iterate, for we are convinced that a swimming bath would amply repay the expense incurred and contribute to the town's exchequer.

In referring to the good work done by the Club, we must mention first of all the name of Mr. H. S. Martin, the honorary secretary. Mr. Martin, a swimmer of note, and a champion on several occasions, has been the life and soul of the Club since its commencement, and the many years of hard work which he has spent upon it are well repaid by the excellent results which his energy has obtained. To him it may be said is due the foundation of the Club and most certainly he is responsible for its brilliant career. Mr. W. F. Sargeant, as chairman of the Club, has ever been a moving spirit, and has largely contributed by his keen and sportsman-like interest to its progression.
Reverting to the sports themselves, those who competed, and also those who attended, as spectators, owe thanks to Mr. A. W. Jessop

and Mr. E. A. Darton for their valuable assitance, and to Mr. Arthur R. Purvis, who undertook the difficult task of judging. Though impossible to give special reference to every event, we must mention as among those of keenest interest the 60 yards handicap for the Sirdar's medal. This was swum off in four heats of seven each, and the first two in each of these were qualified to swim the final. The first heat resulted in a fairly easy win for broomfield with Potts second. Heat two went to Psycha, who beat Darton by barely a foot, and the third heat saw Lloyd come in first with Metzger only two feet behind. In the fourth Gaskell swam an exceedingly close race, being barely a touch in front of Hamilton, but unfortunately the winner of this heat was unable to turn out for the final owing to a sudden indisposition. For the final, therefore, only seven competed, and Broomfield, who was practically limit man, never lost the lead and came in first, with Potts three feet behind and Lloyd a good third. The 360 yards invitation team race between the four rowing clubs of Alexandria created enormous excitement. The contesting teams, the Alexandria Rowing Club, Club Internazionale Canottieri, Club Nautique Francais, and Deutscher Sportsverein, were as keen as possible and the sides of the dock were lined with shouting spectators. The noise and cheering was immense and each supporter urged on his favourite team with lusty lungs. The first swimmer of the Club Nautique Francai was ahead in the first 60 yards and this club maintained its lead until the third swimmer of the Deutscher Sporverein overtook the French Club's man and thenceforward the Germans kept the lead. Mace, however, gained slightly on the German swimmer and when Darton took the water some three yards behind Seeger and the keenest race of the afternoon was witnessed. Both men swam splendidly, but Darton was unable to altogether annul the lead, and Seeger, swimming the greater length of the bath under water came in first by nearly a yard. We must congratulate the Deutscher Sportverein on their second successive win. This event was much better contested than last year, each member of the team thoroughly understanding the race and taking the water at his proper time. Another event of special interest was the polo match between teams of the King's Royal Rifles and the Alexandria Swimming Club. The Club proved itself to be the stronger of the two in scoring two goals to nil in the first half, and in the second they added four more against one scored by K.R.R. Newton. The combination of the Club was excellent, and the players who were especially conspicuous were Darton, Ecclestone, and Glasspole, the first two of whom scored three goals each. Special reference must also be made to "walking the pole". The fancy costumes, as we forecasted, were more numerous and more original than ever. Most realistically garbed as a lobster Metzger thoroughly deserved the costume prize awarded, through a few favoured Jessop, splendidly dressed as a ballrt girl, Ecclestone was excellently got up as a diver, and Verny as an Arab sheikh well sustained the character, with Forzinetti as his partner dressed as an Arab woman. Prosser, as an absent-minded nurse with a much ill-treated infant, caused great amusement, Inglott was a thorough monkey, Glasspole made a very affective geisha, and Randall for the nonce assumed a lady's bathing costume. The diving was very well contested, Ecclestone and Darton tying for first and second places and Jacob and Howard for third place. On the high-dive Ecclestone gained a slight advantage and was awarded first place, while for third place Jacob at a final attempt proved superior to Howard.

The obstacle race caused a considerable amount of laughter. After negotiating the life buoys, goal posts had to be surmounted, and the swimmers had next to get over gates of several bars. After overcoming these obstacles they clambered up the pontoon sides and having attired themselves in shirts again swam the length of the bath, Prosser being declared winner, Glasspole having been disqualified for going under instead of over the barred gate. The juniors' diving was most creditable, and much praise is due to young A.E.R. Ecclestone, a boy of but six summers, who dived from nine feet in splendid style. There is we feel sure a great future in store for all these youngsters who showed admirable form.

At the conclusion of the sports the prizes were distributed by Mrs. N. T. Borton. Mr. Sarjeant in the short and happily worded speech thanked everyone who had worked for the benefit of the most successful meeting they had ever held. He referred in laudatory and well-deserved terms to the energy and enthusiasm displayed by their honorary secretary, Mr. H.S. Martin, without whom, he said, the Club would never have existed, and he expressed his gratitude to all who had so kindly offered such handsome prizes. Mr. Sarjeant especially thanked Mr. and Mrs. E. B. Gould for their attendance and support, as well as all present, and in thanking Mrs. Borton for distributing the prizes he presented her with a handsome card-case. Mrs. Borton in response expressed her thanks for the unexpected gift and her hopes that it would be by no means the last sports of the Alexandria Swimming Club at which she would assist.

An excellent programme of music was played during the afternoon by Mr. Michel Hackmayer's orchestra. Every piece was well rendered, especial attention being given by the spectators to Mrs. M. E. Dandridge's Festal March, which was repeated by special request. Refreshments were supplied by Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi, who fully sustained their good reputation for catering.
Appended is the complete list of events with their results:-
Event I.-60 yards Club Handicap for "The Sirdar Medal" presented by Sir Reginald Wingate, Sirdar, K.C.B., K.C.M.G., D.S.O.,
A.D.C., as a perpetual trophy on which the winner's name will be engraved yearly; and three prizes presented by the Club, the 1st prize being a silver medal in miniature of "The Sirdar Medal."

Heat 1 won by J. Broomfield with J. Potts second. Heat 2 won by P. Psycha with E. A. Darton second. Heat 3 won by C.H. Lloyd with A. Metzger second. Heat 4 won by R. A. Gaskell with D. Hamilton second.
Event II.-60 Yards Juniors' Handicap for three prizes presented by Mr. T. Potts.
Won by A.E.R. Ecclestone (6 years old) with R.F. Ecclestone (10 years) second and W. Keill (15 years) third. Won with ease, A.E.R. Ecclestone proving a much improved swimmer on his time
Event III.-60 Yards Veterans' Handicap. For Members 35 years of age, and over, for three prizes presented by Mr. Walter F. Sarjeant.
Won by T. Potts with D. Hamilton second and G. D. Lovell third. Won by a yard; second and third close together.
Event IV.-Final of 60 Yards Club Handicap.
Won by J. Broomfield with T. Potts second and C.H. Lloyd third. Won by three feet, inches dividing second and third.
Event V.- Juniors' Diving Championship for Silver Challenge Cup presented by Mr. H. S. Martin, and 1st prize by Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi Ltd., 2nd and 3rd by the Club.
Won by J. H. Mitchinson, with A.E.R. Ecclestone second, and H. Elsworth third.
Event VI.- Plunging Championship, for Cup presented by the Alexandria and Ramleh Railway Co. Ltd. and three prizes presented by the Alexandria Tramway Co. Ltd.
Won by C. H. Glasspole with F.E. Howard second and H.R. Inglott third. Winner plunged 51 feet 9 inches; Second 49 feet; 3rd 48 feet.
Event VII.-Polo Match for prize for each member of winning team presented by Mr. J.P. Jones.
Referee: Mr. H. S. Martin.
Won by the Alexandria Swimming Club by 6 goals to 1.
Event VIII.-Three Widths Blindfold Race, (Handicap) for two prizes presented by Mr. Paul Cavafy.
Won by F. E. Howard with J. W. M. Whitfield second.
Event IX.- Diving Championship, for Silver Challenge Cup, presented by Mr. Walter F. Sarjeant, 1st prize presented by Messrs. Davies Bryan & Co., 2nd and 3rd by the Club.

The test comprised at least one standing graceful dive from heights about 3, 9 and 14 feet, and one running dive from spring board. On entering the water the arms must be extended in advance of the head, the four fingers in contact, and the palms of the hands held either downwards or together. The thighs and legs, from the hips to the toes, must be kept closed and straight and the feet turned back until the instep is nearly in a line with the shin. No dive is counted during which the competitor deviates from the above conditions or turns on his back on entering the water. The "Swallow" dive is counted as a plain dive, but the "Buck" dive is not allowed.
Won by A. A. Ecclestone with E. A. Darton second and W. G. R. Jacob third.
Event X.-Obstacle Race (Handicap), for three prizes presented by the Staff of the Eastern Telegraphy Company, Limited
Won by A.N. Prosser with A. A. Ecclestone second and F. E. Howard third.
Event XI.- 360 Yards Invitation team Race, prize for each member of winning team presented by the Club.

In this race, each team is taken as a unit consisting of 6 men in each team. At the word "Go" No. 1 of each team starts and swims two lengths of the bath, and immediately No. 1 has finished, No. 2 of the corresponding team starts, and so on until the six men of each team have completed two lengths each
Team 1.-Alexandria Rowing Club; V. Adds D. Bassiliadis, F. Boriglione, G. Manetta, A. Pandelides, E. Yersin.
Team 2.-Club Internationale Canottieri; A. Gauci, M. Herman, Odoacre Hassman, Oscar Hassmann, E. Papanti, E. Salfati
Team 3.-Club Nautique Francais; E. A. Darton, L. Forzinetti, H. R. Inglott, W. O. Mace, A. Metzger, A. Verny.
Team 4.-Deutscher Sportverein; E. Eichler, K. Hoffman, M. Lindemann, E. Seeger, H. Vogel, R. Yansen.
Won by the Deutscher Sportverein.
Event XII.-Military Tug-of-War. Prize for each member of winning team presented by the Club.
Teams of the Kings Royal Rifles. Won by 2 pulls to 0.

Event XIII.-Walking the Pole. One prize for obtaining flag, one prize for best costume presented by Mr. T. H. Marsden. Prize for taking the flag won by C. H. Glasspole. Prize for the best costume won by A. Metzger. A special prize was awarded to C. E. L. Randall, who took the flag four times, though breaking it twice.
Owing to the failing light, the cock-fighting and bobbing for corks had to be abandoned.

div.head: Egyptian State Railways.
div.p: CONDITIONS OF SALE.
EMPTY PETROLEUM TINS

The Egyptian State Railways have the honour to bring to the notice of the public that they will receive up to the 5th November 1907 offers for the purchase of the following approximate number of Empty Petroleum Tins viz: 20,000 (twenty thousand) complete and in serviceable condition.
These tins will be delivered at the following places: Minieh, Boulac No. 1, Tanta, and Gabbary Stores, and shall not be allowed to accumulate to more than 200.
Those at Gabbary will be handed over to the purchser on the Hilmieh Platform and must be carted away at his own expense.

All the handling and transport expenses in loading and unloading of wagons and carts in connection with the tins shall be born by the purchaser. To avoid deterioration, when about 200 tins have been collected at any of the above Stores, the purchser will be informed by writing, and if they are not removed within ten days from the date of the letter, a fine of one mill. per diem per tin will be inflicted.

Tenderers will pay beforehand a provisional deposit of L.E. 5 (Five Egyptian Pounds) and the successful tenderer will then increase this amount to 10% (ten per cent.) of the value of the sale. The latter sum should be paid within 10 (ten) days from the date of the letter notifying that his offer has been accepted.
The deposit will be retained until the completion of the contract and the Egyptian State Railways reserve the right to divide the sale of the different lots as they see fit.
Cairo, October 10th 1907.

div.head: Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat Egyptien
div.p: AVIS

L'Administration a l'honneur de porter a la connaissance du Public qu'il sera procede, le Vendredi dix-huit Octobre courant, a neuf heures du matin aux Magasins Generaux de Boulac (Cairo), a la Vente aux encheres publiques, suivant Kaimat Mazad, de cent tonnes environ de vieux bois et dechets hors d'usage provenant des travaux du Service des Ponts, qui se trouvent an chantier du Service des Ponts a Ramlet Boulac (Caire), ou on peut les examiner chaque jour de neuf heures du matin a midi, les Dimanches et jours feries exceptes.

Les conditions de vente relatives a ces materiaux peuvent etre consulteesau Bureau de Mr. le Chef du Service des Magasins Generaux a Boulac, Caire, chaque jour de neuf heures du matin a une heure p.m. les Dimanches et jours feries exceptes

Pour etre admis a concourir, le soumissionnaire devra, au prealable, verser a la Caisse Centrale de l'Administration au Caire, une somme de L.E. 10 (dix Livres Egyptiennes) a titre de depot provisoire. Le soumissionnaire declare adjudicataire devra parfaire cette somme jusqu'a concurrence du 10% (dix pour cent) du montantde l'offre agreee et enlever a ses frais les lots qui lui seront adjuges dans un delai de trente jours a compter de la date de l'avis d'acceptation de son offre.

Les offres pourront etre taites sur papier timbre de trente milliemes, si l'interesse ne peut pas assister aux encheres publiques, et dans ce cas la soumission ainsi que le recu du versement du depot provisoire seront adresses par la poste sous pli recommande a:
"Mr. le Chef du Service des Magasins Genraux des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat a Boulac Caire"
et sous double enveloppe, l'interieure portant la suscription suivante:
"Offre pour Achat de vieux bois et de dechets."
Toute offre faite ou deposee ulterieure ment au jour et a l'heure ci=dessus designes ne sera pas prise en consideration.
L'Administration ne s'engage pas a accepter les prix les plus eleves ni a donner suite aux soumissions presentees. Elle se reserve le droit de diviser la vente.
Le Caire, le 5 Octobre 1907.

div.head: Notices to Advertiser.
div.p: The "Egyptian Gazette" has given no advertising agency or company in Egypt any monopoly or exclusive right to act as advertising Agents on its behalf. Advertisements of every description are received at the offices of the "Gazette" from advertisers direct.
